DataElement.preferredName: Metastatic Diagnosis Hepatocellular Carcinoma Risk Factor History Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: An individual's attribute, characteristic or exposure that increases the likelihood of developing a disease that arises from hepatocytes resulting in hepatocellular carcinoma, or as diffuse liver involvement.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any diagnosis indicating the presence of metastatic disease._A record of an individual's attribute, characteristic or exposure that increases the likelihood of developing a disease or injury. (WHO)

ValueDomain.preferredName: Hepatocellular Carcinoma Risk Factor History Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor that arises from hepatocytes. Hepatocellular carcinoma is relatively rare in the United States but very common in all African countries south of the Sahara and in Southeast Asia. Most cases are seen in patients over the age of 50 years, but this tumor can also occur in younger individuals and even in children. Hepatocellular carcinoma is more common in males than females and is associated with hepatitis B, hepatitis C, chronic alcohol abuse and cirrhosis. Serum elevation of alpha-fetoprotein occurs in a large percentage of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma. Grossly, hepatocellular carcinoma may present as a single mass, as multiple nodules, or as diffuse liver involvement. Microscopically, there is a wide range of differentiation from tumor to tumor (well differentiated to poorly differentiated tumors). Hepatocellular carcinomas quickly metastasize to regional lymph nodes and lung. Lately, an increasing number of tumors have been treated with liver transplantation._A record of an individual's attribute, characteristic or exposure that increases the likelihood of developing a disease or injury. (WHO)_A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

PermissibleValues.value: Unknown: Could not be determined or unsure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An indication that something is indeterminate or unknown.

Concepts.definition: An indication that something is indeterminate or unknown.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genetic disorder characterized by decreased alpha-1 antitrypsin activity in the lungs and blood and deposition of alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the hepatocytes. These abnormalities result from defective production of alpha-1 antitrypsin and lead to the development of emphysema, cirrhosis, and liver failure.

Concepts.definition: A genetic disorder characterized by decreased alpha-1 antitrypsin activity in the lungs and blood and deposition of alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the hepatocytes. These abnormalities result from defective production of alpha-1 antitrypsin and lead to the development of emphysema, cirrhosis, and liver failure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term referring to fatty replacement of the hepatic parenchyma which is not related to alcohol use.

Concepts.definition: A term referring to fatty replacement of the hepatic parenchyma which is not related to alcohol use.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An inherited metabolic disorder characterized by iron accumulation in the tissues.

Concepts.definition: An inherited metabolic disorder characterized by iron accumulation in the tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An RNA virus, causes non-A and non-B Hepatitis and liver cancer

Concepts.definition: A viral infection caused by the hepatitis C virus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A viral infection caused by the hepatitis B virus.

Concepts.definition: A viral infection caused by the hepatitis B virus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: consumption of liquids containing ethanol; includes the behavior of drinking the alcohol.

Concepts.definition: Consumption of liquids containing ethanol, including the behaviors associated with drinking the alcohol.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination that an individual's risk factor history is negative.

Concepts.definition: The determination that an individual's risk factor history is negative.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Hepatocellular Carcinoma Risk Factor History Category
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor that arises from hepatocytes. Hepatocellular carcinoma is relatively rare in the United States but very common in all African countries south of the Sahara and in Southeast Asia. Most cases are seen in patients over the age of 50 years, but this tumor can also occur in younger individuals and even in children. Hepatocellular carcinoma is more common in males than females and is associated with hepatitis B, hepatitis C, chronic alcohol abuse and cirrhosis. Serum elevation of alpha-fetoprotein occurs in a large percentage of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma. Grossly, hepatocellular carcinoma may present as a single mass, as multiple nodules, or as diffuse liver involvement. Microscopically, there is a wide range of differentiation from tumor to tumor (well differentiated to poorly differentiated tumors). Hepatocellular carcinomas quickly metastasize to regional lymph nodes and lung. The overall median survival of untreated liver cell carcinoma is about 4 months. The most effective treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma is complete resection of the tumor. Lately, an increasing number of tumors have been treated with liver transplantation.:A record of an individual's attribute, characteristic or exposure that increases the likelihood of developing a disease or injury. (WHO):A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

Concepts.definition: A malignant tumor that arises from hepatocytes. Hepatocellular carcinoma is relatively rare in the United States but very common in all African countries south of the Sahara and in Southeast Asia. Most cases are seen in patients over the age of 50 years, but this tumor can also occur in younger individuals and even in children. Hepatocellular carcinoma is more common in males than females and is associated with hepatitis B, hepatitis C, chronic alcohol abuse and cirrhosis. Serum elevation of alpha-fetoprotein occurs in a large percentage of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma. Grossly, hepatocellular carcinoma may present as a single mass, as multiple nodules, or as diffuse liver involvement. Microscopically, there is a wide range of differentiation from tumor to tumor (well differentiated to poorly differentiated tumors). Hepatocellular carcinomas quickly metastasize to regional lymph nodes and lung. The overall median survival of untreated liver cell carcinoma is about 4 months. The most effective treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma is complete resection of the tumor. Lately, an increasing number of tumors have been treated with liver transplantation.
A record of an individual's attribute, characteristic or exposure that increases the likelihood of developing a disease or injury. (WHO)
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
